'''Repugnancy [[cost]]s''' are costs borne by an individual or entity as a result of a stimulus that goes against that individual or entity's cultural mores.<ref>[[Alvin E. Roth|Roth, Alvin E.]] (2007), "Repugnance as a constraint on markets," November, Journal of Economic Perspectives, vol. 21 (3), Summer, pp. 37-58.</ref><ref>[[Alvin E. Roth|Roth, Alvin E.]] (2007), "What Have We Learned From Market Design?," NBER Working Papers 13530, National Bureau of Economic Research, Inc. </ref><ref>[[Michael J. Sandel|Michael Sandel]] (April 24, 2012), "What Money Can't Buy: The Moral Limits of Markets," [[Farrar, Straus and Giroux]], ISBN 978-0-374-20303-0 </ref><ref>[http://www.economist.com/node/21559308 Two new books probe the limits of capitalism] July 21st 2012 [[The Economist]]</ref> The cost could be emotional, physical, mental or figurative. The stimulus could be anything from food to people to an idea.
These costs are perspective-dependent and individual. These costs may be different for different groups of people; countries, states, ethnicities, etc.<ref>Elias, Julio J. (2008),[http://www.bcentral.cl/conferencias-seminarios/seminarios/pdf/Elias_Repugnance.pdf "The Role of Repugnance in the Development of Markets: The. Case of the Market for Kidneys for Transplants,"] Working paper.</ref> The term allows for a clear and understandable way of representing the concept of contextual stigma in a literal and applicable sense.
== Origin == Repugnancy costs were first mentioned in a debate between [[Alvin E. Roth|Alvin Roth]] and Julio Elias on whether there should be an official [[Gary Becker|market for kidneys]].<ref>Elias, Julio J. and [[Alvin E. Roth|Roth, Alvin E.]] (2007),[http://online.wsj.com/article/SB118901049137818211.html "Econ One on One: A Market for Kidneys?"] The Wall Street Journal Online. </ref> The act of buying and selling [[organ transplant|organs]] may be against one's cultural mores; it may be repugnant. Hence, this is an additional costs one must bear if such a market was deemed repugnant in the context of one's culture.
